Topic.Title: "Future Windows 8.1 tablets to tap Qualcomm chip"

Message.Msg: There is a very good reason that Microsoft has been talking up Qualcomm. Windows RT was supposed to have multiple SoCs supported at launch. But only Nvidia had working device support, because Nvidia was the only ARM SoC vendor with an experienced software team. The poor sales caused most other vendors to abandon Windows support, concluding that there was only room for a single profitable vendor. Microsoft desperately wants multiple vendor support, thus the intensive courting of Qualcomm. The Balmer appearance at CES in January was the highest profile example of this. I had expected that Qualcomm would come out with working support soon after that appearance. It's now 5 months later, and it's yet to arrive. Apparently Nvidia really *is* the only company that has the competence. Qualcomm's entry isn't positive news for Nvidia, but the real negative news was long ago, with the market failure of Windows RT. Microsoft could have recovered from the misstep by getting their internal teams to actually support ARM. But instead they fell flat on their face with only toy support. and a message that it wouldn't get better.

Topic.Title: NVIDIA showing off new "DirectStylus" capabilities for Tegra 4 tablets

Message.Msg: The beautify of the DirectStylus technology, as well as its marketing appeal, lies in the following: 1. You can use a CHEAP, passive stylus to achieve the same as Samsung S Pen technology (in Galaxy Note) with line-width control by pressure 2. No limit on stylus size as in the case of Samsung S Pen which needs to be 1.5 mm or smaler 3. No additional dedicated digitizer needed - the latter is costly! 4. DirectStylus technology is manufacturer-agnostic, unlike Samsung's proprietary technology. I'd say this is a major winning technology, altho it doesn't sound terribly sexy on the surface.

Topic.Title: "Future Windows 8.1 tablets to tap Qualcomm chip"

Why would QC need so much help? ....ok, I won't bring up the sad story of last year: QC made so much noise early about being in the original Surface RT and 3 other similar tablets, only to find itself way behind NVIDIA and, after 2 cancellations, nabbed only a second-tier OEM in DELL. The two OEMs who cancelled partnership with QC were: HP and Samsung.
